bestBHT.bht: The office of the Comforter is to connect the disciples with the Father, so if they did not have Him, they would be left fatherless. The presence of Christ by the Spirit is very real, even though it may be incomplete. Jesus promised that He would not leave His disciples in a bereaved and desolate condition, like orphans. He assured them that He was coming to them by the Spirit, so His departure would not leave them without comfort.

Henry Alford: The office of the Comforter is to connect the disciples with the Father: if therefore they had Him not, they would be fatherless.
The coming is (as there) the summary of these—the great Revisitation, in all its blessed progress.
The presence of Christ by the Spirit is none the less real, for being incomplete.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: I will not leave you comfortless—in a bereaved and desolate condition; or (as in Margin) 'orphans.'
I come" or "am coming" to you; that is, plainly by the Spirit, since it was to make His departure to be no bereavement.
Albert Barnes: He says that he would show them the kindness of a parent, and, though he was going away, he would provide for their future welfare.
And even while he was absent, yet they would sustain to him still the relation of children.
Though he was to go away to heaven, yet he would return again to them.
Marvin Vincent: He hath not left us without a rule; nor without an example; nor without a motive; nor without a strength; nor without a warning; nor without a Comforter; nor without a reward.
I will come [ερχομαι] . Present tense, I come.
John Calvin: They are orphans, exposed to every kind of fraud and injustice, incapable of governing themselves, and, in short, unable of themselves to do any thing.
The only remedy for so great a defect is, if Christ govern us by his Spirit, which he promises that he will do.
It is, by the power of his Spirit; and hence it is evident, that the grace of the Spirit is a striking proof of his Divinity.
Philip Schaff: I will not leave you desolate: I come to you."
The disciples were the ‘little children’ of Jesus...He may therefore well speak to them as a father."
Not from Pentecost, but from the moment of His reunion to the Father, and by means of the Spirit of truth, He comes to them.
Archibald T. Robertson: I will not leave... to send away, to leave behind." (John 14:18)
Desolate... bereft of parents, and of parents bereft of children." (John 14:18)
I come... Futuristic present as in verse John 14:3." (John 14:18)
John Gill: I will not leave you comfortless,.... Gr. 'orphans', or 'fatherless'.
Christ stands in the relation of a Father to his people, and they are his children, his spiritual seed and offspring.
Christ promises that he would not leave them thus, at least not long: I will come to you; in a very short time, as he did.
John Wesley: I will not leave you orphans — A word that is elegantly applied to those who have lost any dear friend.
I come to you — What was certainly and speedily to be, our Lord speaks of as if it were already.

The office of the Comforter is to connect the disciples with the Father, so without Him, they would be fatherless or bereaved. The coming of the Comforter is the summary of the great Revisitation, and even though the presence of Christ by the Spirit is incomplete, it is nonetheless very real. Jesus promises that He will not leave them desolate or as orphans, but that He will come to them through the Spirit. This coming is to make sure that His departure does not leave them bereaved, and is in fact a futuristic present reality. Jesus assures His disciples that He will not leave them without a rule, an example, a motive, a strength, a warning, a Comforter, or a reward. He provides for their future welfare even after His departure.
